learning_outcomes.description: Understand various issues and principles in language test development
Appraise the value of language test items and language test designs
Understand wide social and ethical issues surrounding language assessment
Develop the ability to think critically about research findings in language assessment and testing
Collaboratively design and develop a communicative language test in a specific context and present previous and current work in a seminar context

assessments.task_description:
This assessment contains two parts: Reflection and Reading.

Part 1 – Reflection (3 marks)

This is not a summary task. You do not need to explain every detail. Focus on your own thinking, questions, and learning experience.

Instructions

Write one paragraph that includes Question 1 (required) and at least two other questions below. You do not need to answer all the questions. Please put the word count at the end of your answer.

Use the guiding questions below to write a critical reflection that includes:

  • your personal response to the class (thoughts, reactions, or feelings),
  • analysis of why you responded in this way,
  • reflection on what has influenced your thinking (e.g., prior experience, beliefs, or expectations),
  • one concrete action you would take in future teaching or learning.

Q1. Testing and assessment (Week 1 content)

Identify one specific moment from this week’s class (e.g. an example, activity, comment, or discussion) that influenced your understanding of testing or assessment.

In your reflection, explain:

  • what you initially believed about testing/assessment before the seminar,
  • what changed, was challenged, or became more complex for you,
  • how this may influence a specific decision you would make in your future teaching.

Choose at least two of the following:

Q2. Describe one idea that surprised or unsettled you. Why did you react this way?

Q3. Identify something you thought you already understood, but which you now see differently or more clearly. What caused this shift?

Q4. Explain your current belief about testing and assessment. What experiences (inside or outside the seminar) seem to shape this belief?

Q5. Describe how this seminar connects to your developing identity as a language teacher or professional.

Q6. Identify one aspect of the seminar that supported or hindered your learning. Why did it affect you in this way?

Q7. Name one concept, example, or question you would like to explore further, and explain why it matters to your learning.

 What we are looking for:

  • Reference to your own class experience, not general theory
  • Evidence of thinking, questioning, or change, not polished answers
  • Clear links between beliefs, experiences, and future action
  • Language accuracy is less important than clarity and reflection.

Reflection and AI Use

Reflection tasks in this course are designed to support your own learning process, including moments of uncertainty, difficulty, or change in understanding. You may use AI tools after engaging with the task yourself to clarify concepts or check understanding, however it may not be useful to utilise AI to generate reflective responses, personal insights, or action plans on your behalf. Reflections must represent your own experiences and thinking, not polished or generic responses. These tasks are assessed for engagement and evidence of learning, not writing perfection. If you are unsure whether a particular use of AI is appropriate, please ask your instructor.

Part 2 – Reading (7 points)

The purpose of this task is to prepare for upcoming lectures and workshops.

 Section 1) (4 points) – Weekly Reading: Each week, you will be assigned a reading (or multiple readings) to prepare for the classes ahead. The readings will be made available to you via the course Blackboard site, along with a list of questions about the key concepts/main points of the assigned chapters/papers. The questions have been designed to guide and focus your reading. You need to answer the weekly set of questions briefly but comprehensively in writing.

 Section 2) (3 points) – Article for Article Presentation. Each week, you will complete a written response to the assigned article. Section 2) starts in Week 2.The task has two clearly labelled parts:

  • Part A: Analytical Summary
  • Part B: Critical Evaluation

This task assesses your ability to read language testing/assessment research critically and selectively, not to reproduce article content.

Part A: Analytical Summary (Approx. 100-200 words)

The summary should explain what the study contributes to the field, rather than retelling the article in detail.

Your summary should:

  • Identify the purpose of the study and its main contribution
  • Briefly indicate the theoretical orientation, data, and method (only where necessary)
  • Highlight the key findings or arguments that matter for applied linguistics
  • ✔ Be selective: a strong summary shows why the study matters, not everything the authors did.


Part B: Critical Evaluation (Approx. 100-150 words)

The critique is your evaluation of the article, not a restatement of the authors’ own limitations. You are expected to demonstrate independent scholarly judgement, supported by evidence from the text. You do not need to address all of the questions below. Select those most relevant to the article.

Possible areas for critique include:

Clarity and framing

  • Is the title appropriate and clear?
  • Is the abstract accurate and representative?
  • Is the purpose of the study clearly stated?
  • Are any claims ambiguous, overstated, or underdeveloped?

Engagement with the field

  • Is the literature review relevant and well-selected?
  • Are any sources misinterpreted or misrepresented?
  • Are important perspectives under- or over-emphasised?

Evaluation of empirical research (if applicable)

  • Is the research question important for applied linguistics?
  • Are the study design, methods, and unit of analysis appropriate?
  • Do the data and analysis support the claims made?

Support your critique with specific examples from the article (e.g., sections or page numbers).

Expectations

  • Clearly label Part A (Summary) and Part B (Critical Evaluation)
  • Focus on analysis and judgement, not description,
  • Use evidence from the article to support your points,
  • Writing clarity matters, but depth of thinking matters more.

Further IMPORTANT INFORMATION (PLEASE READ CAREFULLY)

  • The due date of the weekly assignment is 1 pm on Tuesday for all classes. The assignment site is available every Thursday.
  • If a technical failure occurs when you are submitting your assignment on INSPERA (BEFORE the due date), please take clear screenshots of the issue and send them directly to the course coordinator and your instructor with an explanation of the problem. The course coordinator will advise accordingly.
  • If sick/absent, apply for an extension. Marking and grading for the assignment
  • Marks
  • If you complete both the Reflection and Reading Assignments with high quality, you will receive the full 10 marks (3 marks for the Reflection and 7 marks for the Reading Assignment).
  • Your entry is assessed according to the rubric in the Blackboard for each type of assessment.
  • There are 11 assignments in total. You will get the 10 best scores out of 11 assignments. If you receive 10 each week, you won't have to complete the final two assessments. Or your score for all 11 weeks' assignments will NOT be totalled, but only the 10 best scores will be considered for the final marks. Your entry of the two tasks (i.e., reflection and answers to the questions) will be credited to your assessment. You are expected to submit 10 reflections and reading assignments at a minimum (out of 11). The maximum assignment score for each week is 10. The maximum of the total 10 assignments is 100, which will be converted to 15.

Reflection and AI Use

Reflection tasks in this course are designed to support your own learning process, including moments of uncertainty, difficulty, or change in understanding. You may use AI tools after engaging with the task yourself to clarify concepts or check understanding, however it may not be useful to utilise AI to generate reflective responses, personal insights, or action plans on your behalf. Reflections must represent your own experiences and thinking, not polished or generic responses. These tasks are assessed for engagement and evidence of learning, not writing perfection. If you are unsure whether a particular use of AI is appropriate, please ask your instructor.

Statement on the use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) 

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may help students complete this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

assessments.task_description:
A. Article Presentation (5%)

  1. Form a group of two to three.
  2. Choose one article of interest in the list (the list will be provided in class).
  3. Prepare PowerPoint slides for class presentation.
  4. In your slides, include the main points of the study only. Otherwise, the audience will read the slides rather than listen to you.
  5. You will not be allowed to read notes in your presentations.
  6. After the presentation, the instructor will ask a few questions about the study you presented.
  7. You are asked to lead a five-minute discussion after the presentation. Think carefully about how you will use the allocated 15 mins effectively to show your competence in presenting the research in the article.
  8. In reading the article, summarise the study by providing the following for your PowerPoint slides.
  9.  Background of the study
  10.  Research Question/hypothesis (purpose of the study)
  11.  Significance/value of the study
  12.  Methodology (participants, procedure, instruments, types of data, and analysis)
  13.  Results of analysis
  14.  Interpretation of results
  15.  Conclusion
  16.  Limitations and suggestions for further research
  17.  Critique
  18.  One discussion question
  19. Submission documents
  • You need to save the documents as PDFs, then submit them to Turnitin and the Assignment link. Each link requires the following documents (Only one person in each group needs to submit the documents).
  • Turnitin link - PowerPoint slides,
  • Assignment link – 1) PowerPoint slides, and 2) group declaration of equitable contribution (Note: if a member did not contribute to the project, this would impact her/his total mark)
  • Article Presentation Signup Padlet (Blackboard < Assessments < Assessment #2 Article Presentation & Peer Assessment
  • IF YOU DO NOT SUBMIT TO ALL THREE LINKS, YOU WILL NOT RECEIVE A MARK.

   9. Due - 1 pm on the day before your presentation (e.g., Tuesday 1 pm for the Wednesday classes)

B. Peer assessment (5%) - You will assess your classmates' presentations using the criteria provided. In addition to the mark, you are also expected to give some brief written comments. Your comments will be sent anonymously to the presenter later. You can assess group presentations only in class. If you are absent, you will not be able to assess.

C. Marks of this assessment are a total of 1) the score given by the lecturer (5%) and 2) your participation in peer assessment (5%)

Criteria & Marking:

  • Presentations will be assessed by the lecturer and by peers. This assessment comprises presentation marks (5%) and your participation in peer assessment (5%)
  • The presentation mark is the same for everyone as the group assessment item. If a group member fails to participate, they may be dropped from the group and required to apply for an extension to complete the assessment. Please see the assessment guidelines on this assignment for more details on group work and strategies for working well together. For more information on working with groups, see also https://my.uq.edu.au/information-and-services/student-support/study-skills/group-work.
  • Suppose a group member is absent on the day of the assessment or fails to adequately contribute to the development of the presentation. In that case, the course coordinator will negotiate a solution with the remaining team members.

Statement on the use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) 

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

assessments.assessment_title: Language Testing and Assessment Group Project
assessments.task_description:
In this assessment, your group (3 or 4 members) will design, administer, evaluate, and present a classroom communicative language test. This assessment aims to enhance your group-working skills and test your development capabilities. Your evaluation will be based on the completed test and assessment items and the poster presentation of the test at the end of the semester during Weeks 12-13.

A. Submission guidelines

Materials you must submit for this assessment consist of nine separate components.

  1. Rationale:
  • A brief overview of the test context, including details on intended test takers, their proficiency levels, learning environment (e.g., secondary, primary, university, private language school), and the textbook chapter used as the basis for test development. Provide information that is beneficial to other educators interested in replicating the test.
  • Rationale for test content, addressing what to include in the test (test content) and how to administer it. While detailed summaries aren't necessary, ensure there is enough explanation to understand the rationale behind your design decisions. If applicable, reference the "Checklist for evaluating usefulness" (Bachman & Palmer, 1996).
  • Brief report on pilot testing, outlining any adjustments made to the test content following pilot testing. Expected length: 2-3 pages (1.5/double spacing, 12-point font specified below).

 2. Test Items (Test Paper):

  • Design test papers with length in mind, ensuring they align with seminar discussions. Larger groups are expected to produce more test items.
  • Ensure the test assesses communicative language ability rather than discrete grammar knowledge. Tasks should simulate real-life scenarios for test-takers to engage with.
  • Present the test well-organised to leave a positive impression on test-takers. Consolidate all test items assessing different skills into one document.

3. Guidelines for Test Users:

  • Provide clear instructions for test administrators and assessors to ensure consistent administration and assessment.

4.    Test Specifications:

  • Blueprint of the test, referencing provided sample specifications and discussing them in seminars. Share your specifications with a classmate (not in your group) to gauge their ability to create a different test version using your blueprint.

5.     Additional Materials:

  • Include supplementary materials like listening texts/transcripts, speaking task cards, and marking sheets (distinct from marking guidelines provided in item 3).

6.    Textbook Chapter:

  • Submission of the textbook chapter used as the foundation for the test design.

7.    Timeline and Group Declaration of Equitable Contribution:

  • At the beginning of the project, the group plan the work and draws a timeline. You may use AI to create the project plan.
  • Each group member must declare their contribution to the project, acknowledging any discrepancies in participation that may impact individual marks negatively.

8.    References:

  • List all sources used in the project, ensuring proper acknowledgement and formatting.

9. Additional information - Group declaration form and Project Plan (timeline, who will do which task etc)

10. Poster

  • Prepare a poster for the presentation scheduled for Weeks 12-13. At the presentation, you will be asked to answer a few questions from the audience and instructors.

B. Style of Project Report

Items 1, 7, and 8 above:

  • Font type and size – Times New Roman/Arial, 12 point
  • Margin – 2.5cm for all (left, right, top and bottom)
  • Referencing – APA 7th style
  • Space – 1.5 or double spacing

All other items:

While you can choose your formatting style, please ensure all materials are meticulously formatted and aesthetically pleasing. Remember, these materials represent you as a professional and a University of Queensland student.

C. Criteria & Marking:

Completed projects must be submitted by 1 pm on Friday, 8 May, via a link on the course Blackboard site. Each group must submit a single entry. Poster presentations will be conducted during class seminars in Weeks 12-13. Additional instructions on poster presentations will be provided during workshops. Please refer to the rubric below for a detailed breakdown of the marking criteria.

  • Test Rationale (25%)
  • Test Items (25%)
  • Additional test materials (administration, assessment, listening texts, task card for speaking test, marking sheet (12.5%)
  • Test specification (12.5%)
  • Document formatting (12.5%)
  • Poster (12.5%)

This assessment is a group endeavour, meaning all group members receive the same score. Therefore, successful completion of the assessment requires active collaboration among group members. For comprehensive guidelines on group work and effective collaboration, please refer to the provided assessment guidelines. For more information on working with groups, visit Group work - my.UQ - University of Queensland

Statement on the use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) 

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.

assessments.task_description:
1. Task Description: 

This assessment comprises two parts – a Position paper (1500 words) and an interview

Part 1 Position paper

Choose one of the following topics.

1) Assessing communicative language ability

  • Identify the issues in the assessment of communicative language ability and propose potential solutions to those issues
  • Use your own teaching/learning experience to illustrate and strengthen your argument

2) Social, policy, and ethical considerations in language testing and assessment (here, you can choose to focus on one topic only, that is, either social or policy or ethical considerations)

  • Identify the relevant issues in second language assessment and suggest potential solutions
  • Discuss the implications of those issues for your teaching practice

3) Classroom-based assessments

Please read the following instructions carefully before you start working on your position paper.

  1. This should be a position paper that presents a clear, arguable opinion on a specific issue, using well-researched facts, evidence, and logical reasoning to persuade the audience that your stance is valid, often addressing counterarguments to strengthen the case. Please note that the topics we give you are very broad; once you’ve picked a topic that you’re interested in, you will need to narrow it down and decide on a more specific topic for your position paper.
  2.  To do this, you will need to understand the literature on the topic. For example, within topic 1, “Assessing communicative language ability”, you need to show your understanding of communicative language ability, and you may like to focus on classroom assessment or the context of large commercial tests (e.g., IELTS, TOEFL).
  3. Once you have decided on a specific topic for your position paper, create an outline for the paper. Relying upon literature, theories introduced in the course, and your experience, your position paper should include:
  • An introduction paragraph that introduces the broad topic and the more specific topic. The intro should have a clear thesis statement that clearly states the key argument/viewpoint you want to prove/disprove in your position paper. You may choose to agree or disagree or discuss both sides of a topic/issue. In this intro paragraph, you may also specify how the position paper is organised to provide optimal guidance to the reader.
  • The body of your position paper should include:
  • Explanations/definitions of all key terms/concepts that you consider essential for the reader to understand your arguments. You need to rely on the literature related to your chosen topic to provide appropriate explanations of terms. You need to cite the literature when providing the definition.
  • Several main arguments support your thesis statement. For these arguments, you need to review findings from at least three to five empirical research papers that have been done on the topic you choose and use them to support your arguments. Also, do not just list these studies. Show your engagement with the literature on the chosen topic by discussing (where possible)
  • similarities and differences among the studies with regard to your chosen topic
  • The conclusions or results obtained from these studies and how they might relate to the concepts/theories discussed in the course, as well as your own understanding and experience of the topic.
  • When you include your own personal understanding and experiences, you should go beyond just your “personal thoughts” and rather explore and examine the topic as you have come to understand it from the materials provided in the course, in addition to your own journey in learning and teaching second languages. When appropriate, provide examples to support your argument
  • A concluding paragraph that summarises key points in the position paper

4. Some other notes:

  • Use of headings: You can use headings and subheadings in your position paper to better guide the reader, but this is not compulsory. If you think the different parts of your position paper flow together well without headings, that should be fine.
  • Our course Padlet site provides some tips: https://padlet.com/dian0007/slat7826week12
  • STILL HAVE QUESTIONS? PLEASE CONTACT US!

3. Submission:

  • Write the number of words at the end of your essay.
  • Fill in the self-assessment sheet (given in class and available in BB) and submit it online.
  • No hard copy is required.
  • Check the similarity score by submitting your draft essay to Turnitin TRIAL before submitting your final copy.
  • You must submit your final essay to Turnitin's FINAL site.
  • If you submit to the wrong site, your assessment will NOT be marked.

Part 2 Interview (10 mins)

Students explain how they wrote the document, how they planned it, the decisions they made, and the use of AI. Then, to personalise the interview to the students' assignment, a scenario could be given based on their topic. 

Further IMPORTANT INFORMATION (PLEASE READ CAREFULLY)

  • Students must attend the interview. An interview is assessed pass/fail, but without attending the interview or passing it, students cannot pass this assessment.

Statement on the use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) 

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of the assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students must demonstrate detailed understanding of their written submission during the in-person interview, without the use of AI or MT tools.
